newsitem.title: USA: Clinton confers with aides on line-item veto.
newsitem.headline: Clinton confers with aides on line-item veto.

text.p: President Clinton planned to meet Thursday with his economic advisers to discuss a handful of items in the newly enacted tax bill that may fall victim to his line-item veto powers, the White House said.
Clinton, who signed budget and tax legislation on Wednesday, has until midnight Monday to use the authority he was given this year to veto particular items in the measures.
He said during a news conference Wednesday that he expected to issue a line-item veto -- aware that such a move was certain to prompt an immediate court challenge.
"On line-item veto, our deliberations will continue through the weekend on that subject," White House Press Secretary Mike McCurry said.
"We're down to just a small handful of things that are potential candidates for exercising a veto ... I'd say more one hand," McCurry said.
He said that Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin, White House Chief of Staff Erskine Bowles and others met at the White House Thursday morning to "continue their analysis of some of the provisions."

McCurry declined to say when Clinton would act, other than "sometime before midnight Monday." Aides said privately Clinton might announce his decision on Saturday, during his weekly radio address, or on Monday.
